description: Patterns of natural human conversation including flow, turn-taking, context maintenance, and subtle social cues.

dynamics.description: How humans recover from misunderstandings or communication breakdowns

example_dialogue: Person A: I think we should meet at Cooper's at 8pm.
Person B: At Cooper's...?
Person A: Yeah, the restaurant on 5th Street.
Person B: Oh, Cooper's! Got it. I thought you said 'butcher's'.
examples.psychological_function: Maintains mutual understanding without directly stating confusion

example_dialogue: Person A: So I'll see you on Tuesday— I mean Wednesday, sorry. Wednesday at 3pm.
Person B: Wednesday works fine.
examples.psychological_function: Prevents misunderstanding while preserving speaker's credibility

example_dialogue: Person A: She finally got back to me about the project.
Person B: Do you mean Sarah or Jennifer?
Person A: Jennifer, from accounting.
examples.psychological_function: Prevents misalignment of reference while showing active listening

cultural_variations.distinct_pattern: More frequent use of backchannel responses ('hai', 'so desu ne') during others' turns to signal active listening
cultural_variations.social_meaning: Shows attentiveness and respect without interrupting

cultural_variations.distinct_pattern: Longer tolerance for silence before initiating repair
cultural_variations.social_meaning: Silence viewed as thoughtful rather than problematic

cultural_variations.distinct_pattern: Higher rate of collaborative completion of others' utterances
cultural_variations.social_meaning: Signals engagement and connection rather than interruption

developmental_progression.toddlers: Simple repetition requests ('What?') without specifying source of confusion
developmental_progression.school_age: Targeted clarification questions identifying specific unclear elements
developmental_progression.adolescents: Development of face-saving repair strategies that protect both parties' social standing
developmental_progression.adults: Complex, context-sensitive repair strategies tailored to relationship and setting

conversational_costs.cognitive_effort: Requires tracking what information is mutually understood vs. individual knowledge
conversational_costs.face_threat: Potential embarrassment for both parties in acknowledging misunderstanding
conversational_costs.time_efficiency: Trade-off between clarifying now vs. risking larger misunderstanding later

technological_implications.challenge: AI systems often lack sophisticated repair mechanisms, leading to unresolved misunderstandings
technological_implications.design_principle: Effective conversational agents need strategies to detect potential misunderstandings and offer repair options
technological_implications.example: Providing both implicit repair ('I think you want to know about X...') and explicit clarification options

dynamics.description: How conversational partners coordinate speaker transitions with minimal overlap or gap

core_mechanics.explanation: Changes in pitch, speaking rate, and volume signaling completion
core_mechanics.example: Falling intonation and slower speech rate at end of turn
core_mechanics.variation: Question intonation signals strong expectation of next-speaker selection

core_mechanics.example: Listeners anticipate possible completion points of sentences or phrases
core_mechanics.variation: Trailing off before syntactic completion invites collaborative completion

core_mechanics.explanation: Recognition that a communicative action has been completed
core_mechanics.example: Finishing a story, answering a question, or completing a request
core_mechanics.variation: Some speech acts (greetings, apologies) strongly project specific responses

core_mechanics.explanation: Body language indicating turn completion or holding
core_mechanics.example: Gaze direction, hand gestures, posture shifts at transition points
core_mechanics.variation: Gaze aversion during turn holds speaker role; direct gaze at completion yields turn

transition_types.description: Next speaker begins with minimal gap after current speaker completes
example_dialogue: Person A: I think we should consider the proposal carefully. [200ms]
Person B: I agree, especially regarding the financial implications.

transition_types.description: Next speaker begins before current speaker completes

subtypes.description: Next speaker projects imminent completion and slightly anticipates
example_dialogue: Person A: So I'll see you tomorrow at the [cafe—]
Person B: [Great], looking forward to it.

subtypes.description: Next speaker begins well before possible completion point
example_dialogue: Person A: I was thinking we could try that new restaurant on [Main Street—]
Person B: [Oh I've been] there already, it's not very good.

transition_types.description: Silence between completion of one turn and start of next
transition_types.conversation_effects: Often interpreted as hesitation, disagreement, or processing difficulty
example_dialogue: Person A: What did you think of the presentation?
[1.2 second silence]
Person B: Well... it had some interesting points.

transition_types.description: Brief listener responses that don't take over the turn
transition_types.functions: Signal attention, understanding, agreement without claiming full turn
example_dialogue: Person A: So I was thinking about changing careers—
Person B: Mm-hmm
Person A: —because the current job just isn't fulfilling anymore.
Person B: Right, right.
Person A: And there's this program I found that might help.

cultural_variations.characteristics: Short gaps between turns (200-300ms), discomfort with extended silence
cultural_variations.interpretation: Silence often interpreted as disengagement or disagreement

cultural_variations.characteristics: Longer tolerance for inter-turn silences (up to several seconds)
More cooperative overlap, concurrent speech not viewed as interruption
Greater use of back-channel responses, strategic silence
cultural_variations.interpretation: Silences can carry significant meaning; back-channels show attention without claiming turn

high_status_behaviors: Less use of back-channel responses when listening
More successful maintenance of turn during overlap

gender_patterns.pattern: Men interrupt women more frequently than vice versa in mixed-gender conversations
gender_patterns.research: Multiple studies across professional and social contexts
gender_patterns.contextual_factors: More pronounced in public/professional settings than intimate relationships

gender_patterns.pattern: Women use more back-channel responses than men
gender_patterns.function: Facilitates conversation flow, shows active listening
gender_patterns.misinterpretation: Sometimes misinterpreted as agreement rather than acknowledgment

power_dynamics.contextual_influence: Formal settings (courts, classrooms) have explicit turn-allocation mechanisms that override natural patterns

technological_implications.challenge: Voice interfaces struggle with turn-taking, often interrupting users or leaving uncomfortable gaps
design_principles: Implement variable response timing based on utterance type
Develop better prediction of turn completion points
Provide visual or auditory cues for system listening states
technological_implications.multiparty_complexity: Group conversations require sophisticated speaker tracking and turn allocation

dynamics.description: Process of establishing mutual understanding and shared context between conversational participants

key_processes.explanation: Determining what entities are being referred to in conversation
key_processes.example: Understanding who 'she' refers to in 'She said she'll be late'
mechanisms: Recency principle (most recently mentioned entity is likely referent)
Syntactic cues (grammatical role, position in sentence)
Semantic constraints (referent must satisfy properties mentioned)

types.explanation: Shared knowledge based on community membership
types.example: Professional jargon understood within field without explanation

types.explanation: Shared knowledge based on joint experiences
types.example: Inside jokes and references to past shared events

types.explanation: Shared knowledge from current perceptual environment
types.example: Referring to objects visible to both participants

key_processes.explanation: Drawing inferences beyond literal meaning based on cooperative principle

gricean_maxims.violation_example: Person A: 'How was the party?' Person B: 'Well, the food was good.' (Implies other aspects weren't good)
Person A: 'Do you have the time?' Person B: 'Yes.' (Technically true but unhelpfully brief)

gricean_maxims.principle: Be relevant to the current exchange
gricean_maxims.violation_example: Person A: 'Is John coming tonight?' Person B: 'His car broke down.' (Implies 'no' without stating it)
Deliberately convoluted explanation implies desire to obscure information

example_dialogue: Person A: So the meeting is at 3pm on Thursday.
Person B: 3pm Thursday, got it.
grounding_techniques.function: Ensures critical information is mutually verified

grounding_techniques.description: Demonstrating understanding through contextually appropriate response
example_dialogue: Person A: Could you pass the salt?
Person B: [Passes salt without verbal confirmation]

grounding_techniques.description: Finishing another's utterance to display understanding
example_dialogue: Person A: I think we need to reconsider the approach because the client seems to want—
Person B: —more traditional design elements.
Person A: Exactly.
grounding_techniques.function: Demonstrates prediction of speaker's meaning, showing deep understanding

grounding_techniques.description: Rephrasing another's contribution in own words
example_dialogue: Person A: The current system has too many manual steps and redundant data entry.
Person B: So basically it's inefficient and duplicates work unnecessarily.
Person A: Yes, that's the issue.
grounding_techniques.function: Verifies conceptual understanding beyond surface wording

reference_forms_and_accessibility.when_used: First mention of entity not already in common ground
Entity is uniquely identifiable in context
Entity is currently in focus of attention

reference_forms_and_accessibility.example: 'Went to the store and [∅] bought milk'
reference_forms_and_accessibility.when_used: Entity is subject of connected clause in some languages

misunderstanding_types.description: Listener identifies wrong referent for expression
example_dialogue: Person A: We should ask Julie about this.
Person B: [Thinking of different Julie] She's on vacation this week.
Person A: No, I meant Julie from accounting, not marketing.
Person A: We need to table this discussion.
Person B: [American English speaker] Okay, let's postpone it.
Person A: [British English speaker] No, I meant let's discuss it now.

misunderstanding_types.description: Misinterpreting intended speech act or implicature
example_dialogue: Person A: Do you know what time it is? [Intended as request for time]
Person B: Yes. [Interpreting as yes/no question]
Person A: Well... could you tell me?
Person B: Oh, sorry. It's 2:30.

challenges: Maintaining coherent context over extended interactions
Resolving ambiguous references without visual context
Tracking what information is mutually known versus system-only knowledge
design_principles: Maintaining context model across conversation turns
Appropriate use of referring expressions based on accessibility
technological_implications.emerging_techniques: Use of multimodal cues (visual attention tracking, gesture recognition) to improve reference resolution

dynamics.description: Linguistic and conversational techniques used to manage face threats and maintain social harmony

theoretical_background.definition: Public self-image that every person wants to claim

components.definition: Desire to be appreciated, liked, and approved of
Desire for autonomy, freedom from imposition
components.threats: Orders, requests, suggestions that constrain action

theoretical_background.face_threatening_acts: Speech acts that inherently threaten positive or negative face
examples: Requests (threaten listener's negative face)
Criticism (threatens listener's positive face)
Admissions of failure (threaten speaker's positive face)
Accepting thanks (threatens speaker's negative face)

politeness_strategy_types.appropriate_contexts: Emergencies, clear power differences, intimate relationships
examples: Close the door.
Watch out!
Tell me what happened.
politeness_strategy_types.psychological_function: Communicates urgency, clarity, or comfort with relationship

politeness_strategy_types.description: Strategies oriented toward positive face needs (appreciation, inclusion)

examples: Using in-group identity markers ('buddy', 'pal')
Referencing shared experiences ('Remember when we...')
Using inclusive 'we' ('We should get this done')
Offering or promising ('I'll help you with that later')
Including both speaker and hearer in activity ('Let's solve this problem')
Giving reasons ('I'm asking because it affects the schedule')
Giving gifts, sympathy, understanding
Noticing and attending to hearer's interests ('That's a beautiful watch')
Exaggerating interest or approval ('That's absolutely fascinating!')

politeness_strategy_types.description: Strategies oriented toward negative face needs (autonomy, freedom from imposition)

examples: Question instead of statement ('Could you possibly close the window?')
Hedging ('I was sort of wondering if...')
Being conventionally indirect ('Would you mind...')
Using questions rather than assumptions ('Is this seat taken?')
Being pessimistic ('I don't suppose you could...')
Minimizing imposition ('Just a tiny request...')
Giving options ('You might want to consider...')
Making minimal assumptions about hearer's wants
Impersonalizing speaker and hearer ('It would be appreciated if one could...')

techniques.technique: Communicate speaker's want to not impinge on hearer
examples: Apologizing ('I'm terribly sorry to bother you, but...')
Explicitly acknowledging imposition ('I know you're busy, but...')
Stating the FTA as a general rule ('Passengers must fasten seatbelts')

politeness_strategy_types.description: Ambiguous communication allowing for multiple interpretations

techniques.example: 'It's cold in here' (instead of 'Close the window')
'That dress is quite nice' (implying it's not the best choice)
'Harry's a real fish' (ambiguous about which fish-like qualities)
'How was I supposed to know?' (implying couldn't have known)

politeness_strategy_types.benefits: Avoids directly threatening face, provides deniability

characteristics: Greater emphasis on negative politeness in public/professional contexts
More direct communication relative to many other cultures
Clear distinction between intimates (positive politeness) and non-intimates (negative politeness)
Greater emphasis on positive politeness strategies highlighting group harmony
More attention to social hierarchy in linguistic forms
Higher context communication with greater use of off-record strategies
More elaborate positive politeness rituals (compliments, expressions of concern)
Strong emphasis on hospitality as politeness strategy
More flowery language in formal contexts

contextual_factors.impact: Greater politeness typically used by lower power individual
contextual_factors.exception: Very high power individuals may use deliberate politeness to mitigate power difference

contextual_factors.impact: Greater politeness with strangers/acquaintances than intimates
contextual_factors.qualification: Except in cultures with distinct intimate/formal language forms

contextual_factors.impact: Larger requests typically receive more elaborate politeness strategies
contextual_factors.example: Contrast 'Pass the salt' vs. 'I was wondering if you might possibly have time to help me move this weekend'

challenges: Most AI systems default to direct speech without appropriate politeness calibration
Cultural variations in politeness make universal strategies difficult
Politeness often increases utterance length, conflicting with efficiency goals
design_principles: Adjust politeness level based on request imposition
Include cultural adaptation for politeness strategies
examples: More direct for simple, expected functions: 'Playing music now'
More elaborate politeness for unexpected actions or refusals: 'I'm afraid I can't access that information because...'

dynamics.description: How people structure and share stories in conversation

narrative_components.function: Signals upcoming story and claims relevance/tellability
examples: You won't believe what happened at work today.
Let me tell you about the worst customer ever.
I had the strangest experience yesterday.

narrative_components.example: So I was at the grocery store on Saturday morning, and it was really crowded because of the holiday weekend.

narrative_components.function: Sequence of events forming narrative tension
characteristics: Often told in chronological sequence
Use of historical present tense for dramatic effect ('So I'm standing there and this guy comes up...')
Emphasis on unexpected or problematic elements

narrative_components.function: Indicates significance or point of the story

methods.example: It was the most embarrassing moment of my life.

methods.description: Significance shown through reported thoughts/feelings during event
methods.example: I was thinking, 'This can't possibly get any worse,' but it did.

methods.description: Describing what people did rather than said
methods.example: Everyone in the room just froze and stared at me.

characteristics: Often marked by resolution phrases ('In the end...', 'Finally...')
Provides closure to the complicating action
May be followed by return to present ('And that's why I never go there anymore.')

narrative_components.function: Signals end of story and returns to conversational present
examples: And that's how I learned my lesson.
I still can't believe it happened.
So that's my crazy story.
Continuers ('uh-huh', 'wow', 'really?')
Assessments ('That's terrible!', 'How amazing!')
Clarification questions ('Wait, was this before or after?')

co-construction_features.description: Listeners respond with thematically related stories from own experience
Multiple participants jointly construct a shared narrative

variants.features: Turn-taking, mutual elaboration, negotiation of details

variants.example: Friend adding details to familiar story

narrative_types.description: First-person account of events experienced by narrator
characteristics: High tellability threshold in conversation
Often involves trouble or exceptional circumstances
Functions to establish identity, entertain, or make point

narrative_types.description: Recurring or typical events rather than a single incident
narrative_types.example: Every Sunday we would go to my grandmother's house, and she would always have fresh cookies waiting.

narrative_types.description: Events that didn't happen but could have

characteristics: Linear chronological structure
Resolution orientation (stories expected to have clear endpoints)
Individual protagonist emphasis
Entertainment value highly prized
Circular narrative structures
Connection to place and ancestors
Repetition as rhetorical device
Teaching function primary over entertainment
Indirect communication of main point
Greater tolerance for apparent tangents
Emphasis on contextual elements
Collective rather than individual focus

challenges: AI systems struggle with narrative coherence over extended turns
Difficulty in judging appropriate level of detail and relevance
Managing interruptions and co-construction in storytelling
design_principles: Track audience responses to adjust narrative style
Recognize and respond appropriately to second stories
